dialogues.GRAHAM:
[1]Pleasure, Captain. 
[2]If you please, Captain...

[4]So you won't have to burden your eyes by looking at slaves. Oh, excuse me, they're servants now. This wa y, gentlemen...

[14]Oh, western time quickly loses its meaning here ... I first came as part of the British legation in 1857. But I was soon relieved of m y position, as a result of various...disagreements with the Crown's attitude toward the locals. 
[15]Remember that he is arahitogami. A god in human form. During the last two hundred years no emperor was even seen by commoner. You may look at him, with deference, but do not speak unless you are spoken to. 
[16]That "pup" runs the country no more than I do. He was installed as a figurehead at age twelve when the warlords realized Japan needed a central government. But don't be fooled -- he may be a powerless god, but to these people he's a god nonetheless. 
[17]Gentlemen, may I present General Yoshitaka. He will assist you in training the army.

[37]Nathan. I wanted to leave, too. For three years. You must believe me there is a majest y about these people -- can you imagine what your own country would be if it had half the drive and the discipline and the belief and the bravery of these ridiculous little people? 
[38]My God, it's the edicts...

[41]You sod. Christ, give us. . second here

[47]To make sure you're on the side of God and Country, or to make sure you get the hell out. 
[48]Look who's getting sentimental now. 
[49]An honor. I have followed your activities with great interest. I think the European public would be fascinated by a book about your adventures. 
[50]What is it:? . 
[51]Captain? 
[52]As you suggest. 
[53]I will. 
[54]...And so the days of the samurai had ended. 
[55]And in the years to come the Rising Sun of Imperial Japan would fl y in triumph over Korea, over Russia, even over China. Nations, like men, it is sometimes said, have their own destiny 
[56]As for the American Captain, no one knows what became of him. All that is left is his journal which I have published, according to his last request. 
[57]Some lay he died of his wounds, others that he returned to his own country... 
[58]But I like to think he may have found at last some small measure of the peace we all seek, but few of us ever find. 
[59]Anshinritsumai. [I wish you peace.]
dialogues.BAGLEY:
[1]We need a flag. Find me a goddamn white flag! 
[2]Surrender, damn it! That's an order! 
[3]Nathan, good to see you. 
[4]Sit down. This is Mr. Omura, from Japan, and his two associates who, so far as I can tell, don't have names...

[22]Why do you think we're here, Captain? Because Remington and Colt and Winchester have powerful allies in Washington. We're here to sell a shitload of American guns...and steel...and timber. That shouldn't be bud for a Winchester whore like you to understand.

[37]... 1 don't know what to say, sir. I never would have thought him capable of treason. 
[38]What if he just goes off to the mountains and becomes a damn sheep-herder or some such? 
[39]Captain... ... Sir, the Imperial Army of Japan demands your surrender. If you and your fellows lay down your arms you will not be harmed. 
[40]Captain Algren, we will show no quarter. You ride against us and you are the same as they are. 
[41]A classic "V" ambush. Sonofabitcb is using Welt Point tactics.
